 I know you already knew. ;) Your question in your previous post was a dead giveaway that you already knew the answer. My post was for the benefit for the other guy that his scamming ain't working. The definition angle is just one of several bogus arguments (http://www.quatloos.com/taxscams/taxprot.htm) that scammers like to use on the Internet.
 
 Now regarding the initial point of this thread, too many people like to pretend that income tax (local, state, federal) is the only tax that they pay. The reality is quite different from the story that they are trying to present.
 
 The truth is that people pay many different types of taxes and income tax is just one of them. Some of these "taxes" are often called "fees" like the recycling fee that some jurisdictions charge. In Maryland, there was a proposal for a "surcharge" just for flushing your toilet (dubbed the "flush tax"). There's the gasoline tax. There's the property tax. There's the sales tax. You have to add them all up. 
 
 Different income brackets are affected quite differently from these taxes. For instance, if you earn 15k a year, drive 8,000 miles per year using a car with 22 mpg, you'd pay about $182 in gasoline taxes (assuming 50 cents per gallon gas tax). That's 1.21% of your income going to gas tax. Now if you make 85k, drive 18,000 miles, you'd pay $410 in gas tax. That's less than 0.5% of your income going to gas tax. So the richer guy, driving far more often, pays a less percentage of his income to gas tax than the poorer fellow.
 
 That's why you need to add up all the taxes to make a valid conclusion, not talk about one type of tax (income tax only) and make false conclusions.
 
 The question that must be asked is what percentage of your income actually goes to paying these collection of taxes?
